event.name: The Unseen Hand: A Dialogue on Emergence
event.description: An interdisciplinary panel exploring how complex, organized systems like markets, ecosystems, and cities arise from simple, individual actions without a central coordinator.
event.dynamics: A 90-minute session. The moderator will introduce the core concept and pose initial questions for 45 minutes. The remaining 45 minutes will be dedicated to a cross-panel debate and an open Q&A with the audience.

participants.name: Dr. Anya Sharma
participants.bio: Professor of Philosophy of Science at Stanford University. Dr. Sharma's work focuses on the epistemological boundaries between scientific disciplines and how different fields construct models of reality.

participants.name: Dr. Kenji Tanaka
participants.bio: Physicist from Caltech specializing in statistical mechanics. His research on self-organized criticality in granular materials provides a physical model for emergent behavior.

participants.name: Dr. Elena Petrova
participants.bio: An expert in Evolutionary Developmental Biology (Evo-Devo) from the University of Cambridge. Her work investigates how simple gene regulatory networks guide the development of complex organisms.

participants.name: Dr. Marcus Thorne
participants.bio: An economist from the University of Chicago whose research uses agent-based computational models to study the emergence of market dynamics and spontaneous order.

roles.name: Moderator
roles.description: Facilitates the discussion, ensures a balance of speaking time, poses questions, and fields queries from the audience.

roles.name: Panelist
roles.description: An expert academic who provides insights and arguments based on their specific field of study, contributing to the broader interdisciplinary conversation.
